title: Solarscape: Optimising Solar Farm Locations
text: Solarscape is a geospatial analysis project that identifies optimal solar farm locations by integrating multiple criteria such as solar radiation, land use, infrastructure proximity, and environmental constraints. Using Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA) and GIS, we developed a scoring framework to balance energy generation potential with ecological and social considerations.

Motivation


Project Objective

Identify and map optimal locations based on multiple technical and environmental criteria

Create interactive visualization tools to support planning decisions

title: Lessons Learnt
text:
Lessons Learnt Page

Conclusion & Recommendations
Our GIS-based MCDA framework provides a systematic approach for identifying suitable solar farm locations. Future work could include:
- Incorporating real-world energy yield simulations.
- Refining MCDA weighting based on expert feedback.
- Evaluating policy and economic constraints for large-scale deployment.

title: Solarscape: Optimising Solar Farm Locations
text:
Project Overview
Solarscape is a geospatial analysis project that identifies optimal solar farm locations by integrating multiple criteria such as solar radiation, land use, infrastructure proximity, and environmental constraints. Using Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA) and QGIS, we developed a scoring framework to balance energy generation potential with ecological and social considerations.

Key Insights

Optimal sites: Identified using GIS-based spatial analysis with URA Master Plan 2019 data.
Energy potential: Estimated using solar radiation data from NASA’s POWER LARC.
Constraints: Excluded high-rise urban areas, natural reserves, and offshore islands.
Decision-making framework: Applied quantitative MCDA scoring with suitability thresholds.

Explore Our GitHub Repository | View Project Poster

title: Poster
text: Poster Page

title: Report
text:
Over the past decade, solar energy has emerged as the most viable renewable energy source for Singapore. The Singapore Green Plan 2030 targets a solar energy deployment of at least 2 gigawatt-peak (GWp) by 2030 to meet ~3% of projected electricity demand (Singapore 2021), yet the space required for solar farms (Bloomberg 2024) are not one where land-limited Singapore can generously afford.
Notably, Sembcorp’s floating solar projects have demonstrated the potential of alternative installation methods, expanding solar capacity while providing critical insights into technical and operational challenges of water-based photovoltaic systems (Sembcorp, n.d.). Academic work on solar irradiance forecasting and clear-sky modeling in Singapore’s tropical climate has further enhanced site selection precision and energy yield predictions (Dev, Manandhar, and Lee 2017).
These studies collectively underscore that despite spatial limitations, strategic geospatial planning and supportive policy measures are crucial for Singapore’s transition to a low-carbon economy and long-term energy sustainability.
This report details our approach to using Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA) methodologies using GIS techniques, to identify viable locations for solar farms based on solar radiation, land use, and other infrastructure constraints.

title: Solarscape: Optimising Solar Farm Locations
text:
Project Overview
The transition to renewable energy sources is a critical component of sustainable urban planning and climate change mitigation. Solar energy, in particular, offers immense potential but requires careful site selection to ensure economic viability, minimal ecological disruption, and community acceptance. Our project addresses this challenge by developing a data-driven approach to solar farm siting that balances technical, environmental, and social considerations.
Through the integration of multiple geospatial datasets including solar radiation, land use, topography, infrastructure proximity, and environmental sensitivity, we’ve created a sophisticated model that identifies optimal locations for solar farm development. Our analysis not only highlights prime locations but also quantifies potential energy generation capacity and evaluates potential constraints.
The findings from our project provide valuable insights for urban planners, energy developers, and policymakers seeking to expand renewable energy infrastructure while preserving ecological integrity and addressing community concerns.
Explore Our GitHub Repository | View Project Poster | Download Full Report

Data Cleaning & Preparation
To be filled up

title: Methodology
text:
To be filled up 
Our analysis follows a Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA) approach to rank potential sites.


We evaluated each site based on four key factors:
- Aspect (Sun exposure based on direction)
- Slope (Flat or gentle slopes preferred)
- Proximity to substations (Lower transmission costs for closer sites)
- Proximity to roads (Easier transportation & maintenance access)



Each factor was assigned a suitability score (1-5). The final suitability score was computed using a weighted overlay approach.




Excluded natural reserves, tree conservation areas, and offshore islands.

Applied threshold-based filtering to remove areas below 50% suitability score.

title: Methodology
text:
Launch QGIS 3.40.2
Start a new QGIS project.
Save the project in GIS_Metafolder/QGIS folder. Name the project any name of your choice.

title: Methodology
text:
2.1 Geoprocessing MP19 Subzone

2.1.1 Vector Difference Tool

Extract the Mainland Subzone:

Begin by isolating the MP19 subzone from the dataset.
Filter out open spaces, reserved areas, water bodies, and remove surrounding islands (e.g., Tekong, Ubin) to retain only the main island of Singapore.

Remove Restricted Areas:

Use the Vector Difference tool to subtract polygons representing:

Tree conservation zones (NPARKS)
Nature reserves (NPARKS)
Protected areas (MHA)


Output:

The resulting layer, named viable_areas, will include only those areas that are available and allowed for solar panel installation.

title: Methodology
text:
2.2 Analysis of Aspatial Data

2.2.1 Python Processing of Temperature Data

Temperature Data Extraction:

Use Python scripting within QGIS or an external Python environment to process the temperature dataset.
Calculate the average temperature for each weather station over a period of 180 days.

Output:

Generate a point layer representing weather stations with an attribute field for average temperature.

title: Methodology
section: 2.3 Combining of Temperature to Subzone Boundaries
text:
2.3 Combining of Temperature to Subzone Boundaries

Spatial Join:

Link the temperature point layer to the MP19 subzone polygons by performing a spatial join.
Ensure each polygon inherits the nearest weather station’s average temperature.

Validation:

Verify that each polygon now includes an attribute for average temperature to be used in later analysis steps.

title: Methodology
text:
3.1 Extracting Substation Locations

API Extraction:

Use the OpenStreetMap API (or an equivalent source) to extract the locations of all substations in Singapore.

Resulting Layer:

Save the substation locations as a point layer. This will be used for proximity analysis in later steps.

title: Methodology
text:
3.2 Slope

DEM Analysis:

Load a Digital Elevation Model (DEM) for the study area.

Generate Slope Layer:

Use the QGIS Slope tool (typically found under Raster > Terrain Analysis) to derive a slope layer from the DEM.

Output:

The slope layer is crucial for determining areas that are more suitable for solar panel installations.

title: Methodology
text:
3.3 Aspect

Generate Aspect Layer:

With the DEM loaded, apply the QGIS Aspect Tool found under Raster > Analysis > Aspect.
This tool calculates the direction that slopes face, which can influence solar efficiency.

Output:

Save the resulting aspect layer for further processing.

title: Methodology
text:
3.3 Rasterising layers

Raster Conversion:

Convert key vector layers (e.g., substations, roads, and other critical infrastructure) into raster format.

Method:

Use QGIS’s Rasterize (Vector to Raster) tool, ensuring that the resolution and alignment match your other spatial datasets.

Purpose:

Rasterizing these layers facilitates the overlay and proximity analyses in later steps.

title: Methodology
section: 3.4 Creating proximity map for Roads and Substation
text:
3.4 Creating proximity map for Roads and Substation

Proximity Analysis

For each rasterized vector layer (roads and substations), generate a proximity map.
Use QGIS’s Proximity (Raster Distance) tool to compute distance from each pixel to the nearest feature (road or substation).

Output:

These proximity maps will be reclassified and weighted as part of the multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA).

title: Methodology
text:
4.1 Criteria
The criteria for solar farm suitability assessment include: - Slope: Areas with gentle slopes are preferable. - Aspect: South-facing slopes may be more beneficial depending on solar path. - Proximity to Roads: Accessibility is a key factor. - Proximity to Substations: Easier connection to the grid is desired. - Temperature: As higher temperatures may affect solar efficiency, reclassifying temperature data ensures accurate assessments.

title: Methodology
text:
4.2 Perform Reclassification

4.2.1 Slope

Define Classes:

Based on the slope values from the DEM, reclassify the slope layer into classes (e.g., low, moderate, high) using QGIS’s Reclassify by Table tool.

Criteria:

Assign higher suitability scores to areas with lower slopes.




4.2.2 Proximity to Roads

Reclassification:

Use the proximity map for roads and reclassify the distance values into suitability classes.

Scoring:

Areas closer to major roads receive higher scores, as they indicate better accessibility.




4.2.3 Aspect

Reclassification:

Analyze the aspect layer to determine which orientations receive higher solar exposure.

Adjustment:

Reclassify the aspect values so that slopes facing the optimal direction for solar capture (as per your local conditions and guidelines) receive a higher suitability score.




4.2.4 Proximity to Substations

Reclassification:

Similar to roads, reclassify the proximity map for substations into classes.

Scoring:

Areas closer to substations are prioritized due to ease of connecting to the electrical grid.

title: Methodology
text:
4.3 Tweaking and Refinements

Weight Adjustment via AHP:

Apply the Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) to assign weights to each of the criteria. Initially, the aspect criterion may have been over-weighted, so adjust the weights to balance the influence of all layers.

Incorporating Temperature:

Rasterize the viable_areas layer to incorporate the average temperature attribute.
Reclassify the temperature values using the following scale:


Temperature Range (°C) Score Rationale 26.5–26.9 4 Ideal – Peak efficiency (0% loss) 27.0–27.4 3 Excellent – Minimal loss (0.5–1%/°C) 27.5–27.9 2 Good – Moderate loss (1–1.5%/°C) 28.0–28.2 1 Fair – Significant loss (1.5–2%/°C)

Final MCDA Map Creation:

Overlay all reclassified layers using weighted overlay analysis to produce a final Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA) map.
Set a threshold (for example, 50% score or a value of 0.37 in our case) to delineate areas considered suitable for solar farm development.

Validation and Iteration:

Review the MCDA output. If areas that are classified as suitable (green) or unsuitable (red) do not align with realistic expectations, iteratively refine the weights and reclassification schemes.
Consider additional factors or alternative reclassification thresholds until the output map reliably indicates viable areas for solar panel installations.


Explore Our GitHub Repository

title: Report
text:
Site Suitability Analysis

Identification and extraction of viable areas on Singapore’s mainland by excluding restricted zones (nature reserves, tree conservation areas, protected areas, military zones etc.)
Development of suitability criteria based on physical, environmental, and infrastructural factors

title: Report
text:
Data Processing and Integration

Preprocessing of geospatial data from multiple sources (URA Master Plan 2019, OpenStreetMap, NPARKS)
Rasterization of vector layers for consistent analysis
Generation of derived datasets (slope, aspect, proximity maps)
Standardization of criteria values to a common scale (0-100) to facilitate comparison

title: Report
text:
Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis

Implementation of standardization-first approach for proximity, slope, and temperature factors
Reclassification of standardized values using structured scoring tables
Integration of AHP weightages for balanced criteria evaluation
Calculation of composite suitability scores and identification of optimal sites

title: Report
text:
Visualization and Interpretation

Creation of suitability maps highlighting the most viable locations (top quartile)
Analysis of spatial patterns and key determinants of suitability
Identification of trade-offs between competing factors (e.g., proximity to infrastructure vs. environmental conditions)

title: Report
text:
Validation and Refinement

Sensitivity analysis of AHP weightings to assess robustness
Refinement of methodology based on preliminary results and expert feedback
Comparison of results using different analytical approaches (standardize-then-classify vs. classify-then-standardize)

title: Report
text: Schedule (Gantt Chart)

title: Report
text:
Meeting Minutes: Initial Project Discussion
Date: March 17, 2025
Time: 4:00 PM - 6:00 PM
Attendees: TOH Rui Chen, Chamus CHEW Yat Weng, Jernic YEO Jun Zhi
Subject: Project Scoping for QGIS Solar Farm Analysis Assignment

1. Project Focus Decision

Initial Options Considered:

Wind Farm Analysis
Solar Farm Analysis



Points of Discussion:

Wind Farm Limitations:

Limited existing wind turbine installations in Singapore
Space constraints for new installations
Inconsistent wind flow patterns in Singapore
Limited local data availability

Solar Farm Advantages:

Greater prevalence of existing solar installations (observed on HDB rooftops)
Better data availability for solar installation capacities and locations
More opportunities for land use optimization analysis in QGIS
Alignment with Singapore’s renewable energy initiatives




Decision:
After discussion, the team unanimously agreed to focus on Solar Farm analysis as the primary project direction.



2. Data Requirements and Acquisition

Required Datasets:

Land Use Data:

Extract polygons with LU_DESC of Openspace, Waterbody & Reserved site
Avoid residential, special use, and built-up areas
Exclude natural reserves and parks

Topographical Data:

Slope & DEM/aspect data from hands-on exercise
Solar radiance data from NASA’s POWER LARC website (single point)

Infrastructure Data:

Roads from OpenStreetMap (OSM), clipped with Singapore land use layer
Substation/electrical room locations via OpenStreetMap API (export as KML)
Environmental data (sunlight/temperature)




Data Collection Assignments:

Rui Chen and Chamus to research and gather the identified datasets
Team to refine specific data requirements as project progresses




3. Project Technical Setup

Requirements:

GitHub repository for version control and collaboration
A1 poster for presentation



GitHub Workflow Discussion:

Jernic explained and introduced GitHub workflow version control for team members:

Capability to track various file types (code, Excel, CSV, etc.)
Basic workflow process: pull → make changes → commit → push
Importance of pulling before making changes to maintain synchronization
Recommendation to use GitHub Desktop application for easier management




Points of Disagreement and Resolution:

Repository Structure:

Rui Chen suggested organizing by data types
Chamus proposed organizing by project phases
Resolution: Agreed to use a hybrid approach with main folders for phases and subfolders for data types

Website Platform:

Jernic advocated for Quarto for its integration with R and markdown
Chamus suggested using WordPress for simpler management
Resolution: Selected Quarto to comply with assignment requirements and better technical documentation capabilities

Data Analysis Approach:

Rui Chen recommended focusing on available open spaces first
Jernic suggested a comprehensive approach analyzing all potential land types
Resolution: Decided to start with open spaces for initial analysis but develop a framework that could incorporate other land types if time permits





4. Division of Labor

Task Assignments:

Jernic:

Set up the Quarto website
Configure GitHub repository and workflow
Develop visualization components

Rui Chen:

Lead technical implementation of QGIS analysis
Gather and process land use and topographical data
Research solar efficiency parameters

Chamus:

Collect infrastructure and environmental data
Process and configure scripts for data collection
Documentation and report writing




Assignment Considerations:

Distribution based on technical strengths and previous experience
Balanced workload across team members
Cross-training opportunities to develop new skills

Meeting adjourned at approximately 6:00 PM.

title: Report
text:
Downloaded from data.gov.sg

Master Plan 2019 Land Use layer:

This dataset provides detailed information on land use classifications as per the 2019 Master Plan.

Master Plan 2019 Subzone Boundary (No Sea):

This layer delineates subzone boundaries excluding maritime areas, as outlined in the 2019 Master Plan.

title: Report
text:
Downloaded from USGS Earth Explorer:

Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM):

30-meter digital elevation model data. This high-resolution topographic data is crucial for terrain analysis and modeling. The STRM data set is already provided in the hands-on exercise data folder by the professor

title: Report
section: Downloaded from Malaysia, Singapore, and Brunei at Geofabrik download server:
text:
Downloaded from Malaysia, Singapore, and Brunei at Geofabrik download server:

Roads and buildings data from OpenStreetMap (OSM) data sets. These datasets include vector data representing road networks and building footprints, sourced from the collaborative OpenStreetMap project.

title: Report
text:
Getting location of Substations:

A query script (code located in substation_query.txt) was ran at openstreetmap overpass turbo api site, to retrieve the the substation location in Singapore, before exporting as KML. The KML contains a polygon and point layer, and the polygon was further converted to point using centroid and combined with the point layer using merge vector layers. All field except for Name, Fid, addr_postcode and addr_street was removed, before saving in geopackage as substation_location

title: Report
section: Downloaded from Malaysia, Singapore, and Brunei(https://download.geofabrik.de/asia/malaysia-singapore-brunei.html) at Geofabrik download server:
text:
Downloaded from Malaysia, Singapore, and Brunei(https://download.geofabrik.de/asia/malaysia-singapore-brunei.html) at Geofabrik download server:

Roads and buildings data from OpenStreetMap (OSM) data sets. These datasets include vector data representing road networks and building footprints, sourced from the collaborative OpenStreetMap project.

section: Downloaded from Malaysia, Singapore, and Brunei at Geofabrik download server](https://download.geofabrik.de/asia/malaysia-singapore-brunei.html):

Downloaded from Malaysia, Singapore, and Brunei at Geofabrik download server](https://download.geofabrik.de/asia/malaysia-singapore-brunei.html):

Roads and buildings data from OpenStreetMap (OSM) data sets. These datasets include vector data representing road networks and building footprints, sourced from the collaborative OpenStreetMap project.

title: Report
text:
Downloaded from Geofabrik download server:

Roads and buildings data from OpenStreetMap (OSM) Malaysia, Singapore, and Brunei data sets.
These datasets include vector data representing road networks and building footprints, sourced from the collaborative OpenStreetMap project.

title: Report
text:
Processed from Overpass Turbo:

We wrote a query script (code located in substation_query.txt) and ran it in the Openstreetmap Overpass Turbo API site, to retrieve the the substation location in Singapore, before exporting as KML.
The KML contains a polygon and point layer, and the polygon was further converted to point using centroid and combined with the point layer using Merge Vector Layers.
All fields except for Name, Fid, addr_postcode and addr_street was removed, before saving in geopackage as substation_location.
